content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Nancy Anderson: Well, I was born in Evanston, Illinois, and I grew up in a small but tight-knit community. My parents were both hardworking people—my father worked as an engineer, and my mother was a teacher. We had a modest but comfortable life, and I always felt lucky to have both of them around. I remember my father often coming home with stories from work, and my mother would read to me every night before bed. I went to school in Evanston, and I was pretty good at math and science, which I think came from my father's influence. I ended up going to college in the same state, where I earned a Bachelor's degree in Business Administration. After college, I moved to Chicago for a few years to work in finance, but I eventually decided to come back to Evanston because I missed the slower pace and the sense of community. I met my husband, Mark, while I was working in Chicago—he was a software developer, and we bonded over our love for classic rock and long weekend hikes. We got married a few years ago, and we've been trying to start a family, though it's been a bit of a journey. Life hasn't always been easy, but I've always tried to stay positive and focus on what I can control.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Nancy Anderson: Yes, there was a moment that really shaped the direction of my life. After I graduated from college with my Bachelor's in Business Administration, I had two main options: take a job at a local firm in Evanston or move to Chicago for a more prestigious position with a larger company. I was tempted by the bigger salary and the chance to climb the corporate ladder, but I also knew that moving to Chicago would mean leaving behind the close-knit community I grew up in, not to mention the comfort of my parents' home. I remember sitting at my father's kitchen table, staring at the job offer letter, and really thinking about what kind of life I wanted. I realized that while the Chicago job might offer more financial security, I didn't want to lose the sense of connection and stability that Evanston gave me. So I chose to stay local, and that decision ended up being the right one for me. It allowed me to build a career here, eventually start my own small business consulting firm, and stay close to my family. Looking back, I think that moment was a turning point because it taught me the importance of aligning my choices with my values, even if it meant taking a less obvious path.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Nancy Anderson: I think I made a conscious choice, though it wasn't always clear at the time. I remember feeling a bit of anxiety about turning down the Chicago job, because I didn't want to be seen as settling for less. But I also knew that I valued the relationships I had here more than I valued the idea of climbing a corporate ladder. I think it was a combination of intuition and reflection—like I was really listening to myself, even if I didn't have all the answers. In the end, I made a decision that felt true to who I was, and that gave me a sense of peace I couldn't have gotten from a bigger paycheck. I think that's what I mean by making a conscious choice—it wasn't just about what was in front of me, but about what I believed in and what I wanted my life to look like.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Nancy Anderson: Absolutely, I think having someone to talk to during that time would have helped. My mother, for instance, was someone I could always count on. She had a way of putting things into perspective without being judgmental. I remember talking to her one evening, and she simply said, 'Nancy, you don't have to be the best at everything to be happy.' That really stuck with me. I also think a career counselor might have been useful—someone who could have helped me weigh the pros and cons of each path more objectively. But in the end, I think the decision was mine to make, and I needed to trust my own instincts. I'm grateful I had the support of my family, even if I didn't always realize it at the time.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Nancy Anderson: Yes, I have a partner—Mark, the software developer I met in Chicago. We've been married for about six years now, and while our lives have been busy, we've always made an effort to keep our relationship strong. We both love the outdoors, so we try to take long hikes on the weekends, often exploring the nearby trails in the North Shore area. We also enjoy cooking together, especially on the weekends when we can take our time. As for children, we've been trying to start a family for a few years now, and while it's been a bit of a journey, we're both very hopeful and supportive of each other through it all. It's not easy, but I think it's strengthened our bond. My parents are still very much a part of our lives too—my father still works part-time as a consultant, and my mother volunteers at the local library. They're both very active in our community, and I feel lucky to have them around. Family has always been really important to me, and I think that's something I inherited from my parents, who always put family first.

Going through the interview questions made me reflect on how much my values and relationships have shaped the path I've taken. From my childhood in Evanston to the decision to stay local after college, I've always prioritized connection and community over personal ambition. The choice I made at that crossroads wasn't just about a job—it was about staying true to who I am and what matters most to me. I'm grateful for the support of my family, especially my mother, whose wisdom helped me see things more clearly. Now, as I navigate life with Mark and continue to build our future together, I'm reminded that the decisions we make, even the difficult ones, are what define us. It's comforting to look back and see how each step, even the uncertain ones, has led me to where I am today.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Nancy Anderson: My sister, Linda, lives in Milwaukee now. She's a few years younger than me, and we've always had a close relationship, even though we're not as close anymore as we used to be. She moved away after college to pursue a career in healthcare, and while we stay in touch, life has taken us in different directions. I admire her for the work she does, though—it's a demanding field, and she's always been passionate about helping others. We still get together for holidays and family events, and I really value those moments. I think our relationship has changed over the years, but I still feel a deep sense of love and respect for her. It's funny, though, how sometimes the people we think we'll be closest to our whole lives end up having different paths, but I think that's just part of growing up.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Nancy Anderson: Outside of my family, there are a few friends who have been really important to me over the years. One of them is Sarah, who I met in college. We were in the same business program, and we became close because we both had a passion for entrepreneurship. Even though she ended up moving to California after graduation, we've stayed in touch, and she's always been a source of inspiration for me. She started her own marketing firm, and I've always admired her courage and creativity. Then there's my friend Tom, who I've known since high school. He's a firefighter in Chicago, and he's been there for me through some tough times. We don't see each other as often as we used to, but whenever we do, it's like no time has passed. I think having friends like Sarah and Tom has been really important for me—they remind me that life is about more than just work and family, and that it's okay to reach out and lean on others when things get tough.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Nancy Anderson: I live in a quiet neighborhood on the north side of Evanston, just a few blocks from the lake. It's a mix of older homes and newer developments, and there's a real sense of community here. The streets are tree-lined, and there are a lot of families with kids, which makes it feel like a safe and welcoming place. I love that there are local shops and cafes within walking distance—there's this little bakery called 'Maple Street Breads' that my mom frequents, and I've started going there too. The neighborhood also has a lot of parks and trails, which is perfect for Mark and me to take our weekend hikes. I think one of the things I appreciate most about living here is the balance between being close to the city and still having that small-town feel. It's not too busy, but it's never too quiet either. There are block parties in the summer, and people know each other by name. I feel like I'm part of something bigger here, and that's something I really value.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Nancy Anderson: I definitely feel safe here. There's a real sense of watchfulness in the neighborhood—people look out for each other, and there's always someone around if you need help. I've never had any issues with crime, and I think that's one of the reasons I chose to stay in Evanston. It's not just the quiet streets or the friendly neighbors; it's the feeling that this is a place where you can raise a family without worrying about the usual stresses of city life. I know that safety isn't always guaranteed, but I feel like this community has a way of protecting its own in a way that's hard to find elsewhere.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Nancy Anderson: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. One of the biggest downs is the slow pace of change—sometimes it feels like the neighborhood moves at its own rhythm, and that can be frustrating if you're used to more fast-paced environments. For example, when I first started my consulting business, I had to wait a while for the city to approve some permits for a small office space, and that delayed things a bit. But on the flip side, that same slow pace is what makes the community so strong. People take the time to get to know each other, and that builds trust. I also love how the seasons are so distinct here—winters can be cold and snowy, which means cozy nights at home with Mark, and summers are perfect for outdoor activities. There's also a sense of history in the area, with many of the homes dating back decades, which gives the place a unique charm. Overall, I think the pros outweigh the cons, and I'm really happy I chose to stay here.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood made me reflect on how much my sense of belonging and safety contribute to my overall happiness. Talking about Mark, our journey to starting a family, and my parents' continued presence in my life reminded me of how deeply rooted I am in this community. When I described my neighborhood, it wasn't just about the streets or the shops—it was about the feeling of being part of something that feels like home. I think the questions helped me realize how much I value the connections I have with the people around me, and how those connections shape the way I see the world. It's comforting to know that even in the quietest moments, there's a sense of safety and support that I can rely on.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Nancy Anderson: A typical week for me is pretty structured, though there's always some flexibility depending on work and family needs. I usually start my week with a morning walk by the lake, which helps me clear my head and get ready for the day. I work from home most of the time, running my small consulting business, so my days are a mix of client meetings, emails, and planning projects. Mondays are usually the busiest because that's when I catch up on everything from the weekend. Tuesdays and Wednesdays tend to be more focused on deep work, and I try to schedule meetings for the afternoons so I can have some quiet time in the mornings. Thursdays are often a bit lighter, and I like to use that time to run errands or meet up with friends for coffee. Fridays are my favorite because I can wind down a bit more, and I usually have a nice dinner with Mark. On the weekends, we're both pretty active—whether it's hiking, visiting the local farmers' market, or just enjoying a lazy morning at home. I also try to set aside some time each week for my parents, whether it's a phone call or a visit. It's not perfect, but this rhythm works well for me and helps me balance work, family, and the things I love about living here.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Nancy Anderson: I work as the owner of a small business consulting firm, which I started a few years after I decided to stay in Evanston. My work is mostly focused on helping local businesses with strategic planning, marketing, and operations—things I learned during my time in college and through my experience in finance. I work from home most of the time, which gives me a good balance between being able to manage my business and still being present for my family. My typical work hours are from around 8:00 AM to 5:00 PM, though I often end up working a bit later on days when I have meetings or deadlines. I also make time to attend local business events and networking groups, which helps me stay connected with the community and keep my business growing. It's not always easy running your own business, but I love the freedom it gives me to shape my own path and support other local entrepreneurs along the way.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Nancy Anderson: Outside of work and family, I also have a few personal routines that help me stay grounded. I've always been into reading, especially historical fiction and biographies—I find that they give me a different perspective on life and help me reflect on my own choices. I try to set aside at least an hour each evening to read, usually after Mark and I have dinner. I also practice yoga a couple of times a week, which helps me manage stress and stay physically active. It's something I started a few years ago after a particularly busy period in my business, and it's become a non-negotiable part of my self-care. I also volunteer at the local community center a few times a month, helping with events and workshops for small business owners. It's a way to give back to the community that's supported me so much over the years, and I find it really rewarding. These routines might seem small, but they help me maintain a sense of balance and purpose in my life.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Nancy Anderson: One of the more recent changes to my daily routine has been incorporating more mindfulness practices into my mornings. I started this a few months ago after reading a book on meditation and realizing how much I was relying on caffeine to get through the day. Now, I try to spend the first 15 minutes after my walk by the lake sitting quietly, just breathing and being present. It's not always easy to quiet my mind, especially with the demands of running a business, but I've noticed a difference in how I approach challenges. I'm also trying to be more intentional about meal planning, which has helped me eat healthier and spend less time rushing through meals. It's been a small but meaningful shift, and I think it's helped me feel more centered in my day-to-day life.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Nancy Anderson: Well, we don't have children yet, but we're both very hopeful and actively working on building our family. It's been a journey with some challenges, but we've supported each other through it all. If we did have children, I imagine their typical weekday during the school year would start with a morning routine—maybe some breakfast, a quick walk around the neighborhood, and then heading to school. I think they'd probably have a packed lunch made by Mark and me, and we'd make sure to include something they love, like peanut butter sandwiches or a piece of fruit. After school, they might have some time to play or do homework, and then we'd try to fit in some after-school activities. I can only imagine what those might be—maybe sports, music lessons, or something like scouting. I know from talking to friends who have kids that these activities are important for development and socialization. Mark and I would definitely want to be involved, whether it's driving them to practices or helping with homework. It's something we've talked about a lot, and I think we'd both be very committed to being present for them, even if it means adjusting our schedules. For now, we're just focusing on staying healthy, staying connected, and being ready for whatever comes next.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect on how deeply my sense of belonging and daily routines shape my life. Talking about my neighborhood reminded me of how much I value the safety and community here, and how that sense of security contributes to my overall happiness. Discussing my work and personal routines helped me realize how important balance is to me—whether it's through my consulting business, my time with Mark, or my personal practices like reading and yoga. It's comforting to see how my choices, from staying in Evanston to starting my own business, have all led to a life that feels meaningful and grounded. These conversations also made me appreciate the small, everyday rituals that keep me centered, like my morning walks or my evening reading. I think it's these little things, combined with the support of my family and friends, that make life feel full and worth living.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Nancy Anderson: In terms of my health, I'd say I've been pretty lucky overall. I don't have any major chronic conditions, and I try to take care of myself through regular exercise, a balanced diet, and stress management. Yoga has been a huge part of that—helping me stay flexible and grounded, especially with the demands of running my own business. I also make an effort to eat well, mostly because I've always had a good relationship with food, though I'll admit I have a sweet tooth. I love baking, and I often make cookies or cakes on the weekends, which is a fun way to stay connected with my roots. I also try to get enough sleep, though it's not always easy with the demands of work and family life. I've had a few minor health issues over the years, like occasional migraines, but nothing that's ever been too serious. I think the biggest thing is that I've always been proactive about check-ups and staying on top of my health. My mother, being a teacher, always emphasized the importance of taking care of your body, and I think that's something I've carried with me into adulthood. Overall, I feel pretty healthy, and I'm grateful for that.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Nancy Anderson: For me, staying healthy is a mix of what makes it easy and what makes it hard. On the easy side, I really enjoy the routines I've built around yoga and reading—those are things I look forward to, and they help me feel balanced. Also, living in a neighborhood with so many parks and trails makes it easy to stay active, whether it's a morning walk by the lake or a weekend hike. But on the harder side, work can be unpredictable, and there are days when I get caught up in meetings or deadlines and forget to take a break. I also struggle with consistency when it comes to meal planning—sometimes I fall back on convenience foods, especially when I'm busy. I think the biggest challenge is finding the time to prioritize self-care when life gets hectic, but I'm learning to be more intentional about it. I've started setting reminders on my phone to take short breaks throughout the day, and I've also made a point to schedule my yoga sessions like I would a meeting. It's not perfect, but these small steps help me stay on track.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Nancy Anderson: In the past two years, I've been dealing with some recurring lower back pain, which I think is related to the long hours I spend sitting at my desk while running my business. It started as a mild discomfort, but over time, it became more persistent, especially after long days of meetings or deep work. I finally made an appointment with a physical therapist, and through a combination of exercises and posture adjustments, I've been able to manage it much better. It was a reminder that even though I take care of my body in some ways, I still need to be more mindful of how I sit and move throughout the day. I also started incorporating more stretching into my routine, which has helped a lot. It's not something I'm proud of, but it's been a learning experience—showing me that health isn't just about being active or eating well, but also about paying attention to the small things that can affect your body over time.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Nancy Anderson: Honestly, the back pain hasn't really gotten in the way of my work or my ability to care for Mark, but it has made me more aware of how important it is to take care of my body in all aspects. There were a few days when I was so stiff that I had to cancel a meeting or two, which was frustrating because I wanted to be fully present for my clients. But I've learned to listen to my body and adjust my schedule when needed. It's also made me more empathetic toward others who deal with chronic pain or health issues—it's not always visible, but it can definitely impact your daily life. I think the biggest takeaway for me has been that health is a continuous process, not a one-time achievement. It's about making small, consistent choices that add up over time, and being willing to adapt when things don't go as planned.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Nancy Anderson: Over the past year, I've been feeling a mix of gratitude and quiet determination. There have been moments of uncertainty, especially as we continue to navigate the path to starting a family, but I've also found a deep sense of contentment in the life I've built here in Evanston. Mark and I have grown closer through the challenges we've faced together, and I feel more connected to my community than ever before. I've also been reflecting a lot on my own growth—how my small business has evolved, how I've learned to be more present in my daily life, and how I've come to appreciate the little things even more. There were times when I felt overwhelmed with work or the pressures of life, but I've also found strength in the support of my family and friends. I think the past year has been about learning to embrace both the challenges and the beauty of the everyday, and I'm hopeful that this continues to be a year of growth and connection for me and everyone I love.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my health and daily routines are intertwined with my sense of balance and well-being. Discussing my recent changes in mindfulness and meal planning reminded me of how small, intentional shifts can have a big impact on how I feel throughout the day. It also made me think about how important it is to listen to my body and not ignore the signals it sends, like the recurring back pain I've been dealing with. I've come to realize that staying healthy isn't just about being active or eating well—it's about being mindful of how I move, sit, and take care of myself in all aspects of life. These conversations also made me appreciate the role of routine in maintaining that balance, whether it's through yoga, reading, or simply taking a few minutes each morning to breathe and be present. I think it's these small, consistent choices that help me feel grounded and ready to face whatever comes next.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Nancy Anderson: I think I've been pretty fortunate in that I haven't struggled with depression or anxiety in the way some people do. That said, there have been moments—especially during the early days of starting my business or when we were first trying to conceive—when I felt overwhelmed or uncertain about the future. I remember one particular time when I was juggling a big project at work, Mark was dealing with a stressful time at his job, and we were still trying to figure out our next steps with family planning. It was a lot to handle all at once, and I definitely felt the weight of it. But I've always leaned on my support system—my family, my friends, and even my yoga practice—to help me through those moments. I think it's important to acknowledge when things feel heavy, even if it's not something that fits into a diagnosis. For me, it's been about finding small ways to cope, like talking to someone I trust or taking a walk by the lake to clear my mind. I don't want to minimize what others go through, but I do feel grateful that I've had the tools and relationships to get through those tough times without needing more formal help.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Nancy Anderson: For my family, the past year has been a mix of challenges and quiet triumphs. Mark and I have been navigating the journey to starting a family, and while it's been a process filled with uncertainty at times, we've leaned on each other more than ever. Our bond has only grown stronger through the ups and downs, and I feel so lucky to have him by my side. My parents have also been a constant source of support—my father has been helping me with some of the more strategic aspects of my business, and my mother has been there with advice, encouragement, and her signature home-cooked meals whenever we visit. My sister Linda has been going through her own challenges with work, but we've managed to stay connected, and I know she's proud of the life I've built here. Overall, I think my family has been holding up pretty well, and I'm grateful for the love and support we've all shared through it all.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Nancy Anderson: For me, religion has always been a quiet presence in my life—something that shapes my values but doesn't dominate my daily thoughts. I was raised Protestant, like my parents, and I still find comfort in the traditions we grew up with, like attending church on Sundays or celebrating holidays with family. But I don't see it as something I need to follow strictly. Instead, I think of it more as a foundation for the kindness and gratitude I try to carry with me every day. I believe in the importance of community, of helping others, and of finding meaning in the small moments, which I think are all things that my faith has helped instill in me. That said, I'm not someone who needs to attend services regularly or follow every rule—I think of it more as a personal guide rather than a rigid structure. I'm grateful for the spiritual grounding I've had, but I also believe that spirituality can come from many places—whether it's through nature, relationships, or even the simple act of showing up for the people you love.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Nancy Anderson: I actually don't use social media very much, and I think that's something I've come to appreciate over time. I used to be on Facebook more regularly, mostly to stay in touch with family and old friends, but I found that it started to take up more of my time than I wanted it to. I noticed that I was comparing my life to others' highlight reels, which didn't always make me feel good. So I decided to step back a bit and focus more on the people and experiences that matter most to me in real life. I still check in occasionally to see what my parents or sister are up to, and I follow a few local business pages for inspiration, but I don't spend a lot of time scrolling through feeds or engaging with content. I think it's important to have boundaries, especially with technology, and I've found that limiting my use of social media has helped me feel more present in my own life. I'm not opposed to it entirely, but I prefer connecting through face-to-face conversations, phone calls, or even old-fashioned letters when I want to stay in touch with someone.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Nancy Anderson: Honestly, I haven't found myself turning to social media for support during tough times, and I think that's because I've always leaned on my close relationships first. When things have gotten difficult—whether it was the stress of starting my business or the emotional challenges of trying to build a family—I've found comfort in talking to Mark, my parents, or my friends. I think there's something about face-to-face conversations or even a phone call that feels more genuine and supportive than scrolling through someone else's life online. That said, I can see how it might help others, especially if they don't have a strong support system in their immediate lives. For me, it's just not the way I've ever processed emotions or sought help. I prefer to keep things personal and grounded, even if that means I miss out on some of the digital connections others rely on.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect on how my health and emotional well-being are deeply connected to the choices I make in my daily life. Talking about my recurring back pain reminded me that even small, overlooked habits—like how I sit or move throughout the day—can have a lasting impact on my body. It also made me think about how I handle stress and uncertainty, especially during challenging times like trying to start a family or running my own business. I realized that while I haven't struggled with depression or anxiety in a clinical sense, there are still moments when I feel overwhelmed, and it's important to acknowledge those feelings without minimizing them. These conversations also helped me appreciate how much my support system—Mark, my family, and my friends—has helped me navigate those tough times. I think the biggest takeaway is that health and emotional well-being aren't just about avoiding problems, but about learning how to move through them with grace, resilience, and the help of the people I love.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Nancy Anderson: In the past year, I've noticed that my stress levels have been more manageable, largely because I've been more intentional about how I care for myself. I think part of that comes from the mindfulness practices I've started incorporating into my mornings, which help me begin the day with a sense of calm rather than rushing into it. I've also been more open about my feelings with Mark, which has made a big difference in how I process worry or uncertainty. When I feel overwhelmed, I try to take a step back—whether it's going for a walk, reading a chapter of a book, or even just sitting quietly for a few minutes. I've also been more mindful of setting boundaries at work, which has helped me avoid burnout. I think the biggest shift has been learning to accept that I can't control everything, and that it's okay to let go of the things that are out of my hands. It's not always easy, but I've found that these small, consistent changes have made a real difference in how I feel emotionally.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Nancy Anderson: Last month, our biggest expenses were related to my business operations, including rent for the small office space I use part-time, utilities, and client-related costs like software subscriptions and marketing. We also had a significant portion of our budget go toward groceries, especially since I've been trying to meal plan more and eat healthier. Another big expense was Mark's car maintenance—he drives a lot for work and our weekend adventures, so keeping the car in good shape is important. We also set aside money for our upcoming family planning consultations and any potential medical costs that might come with that. On the personal side, I still enjoy baking, so I occasionally splurge on specialty ingredients for cookies or cakes, which is a small indulgence I allow myself. Overall, I try to keep our budget balanced by tracking our expenses closely and prioritizing what matters most—like our health, our home, and our community.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Nancy Anderson: Last month, our household spent around $4,500, which is pretty close to our usual monthly budget. We typically spend about $3,500 to $4,700 each month, depending on how much I'm investing in my business or if we have any unexpected expenses. The bulk of our spending goes toward rent, utilities, and groceries, which are pretty standard for a family of two. I also set aside a portion of our income for my consulting business—things like software licenses, marketing, and professional development. Mark's car maintenance and insurance are another regular expense, and we also have a small amount allocated for savings and any potential medical costs related to our family planning journey. I try to keep things as simple as possible, and I've found that tracking our spending with a budgeting app has helped us stay on top of things without feeling overwhelmed. It's not always perfect, but it gives me peace of mind knowing we're managing our money responsibly.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Nancy Anderson: We rent our home. It's a two-bedroom apartment on the north side of Evanston, just a few blocks from the lake, which is why I chose it. The location is perfect for us—it's close to everything we need, like the local grocery store, the community center where I volunteer, and the parks where Mark and I like to hike. Renting has been a good fit for us, especially since we're still in the early stages of building our family. It gives us flexibility without the long-term commitment of a mortgage, and it's also easier to manage with my business, since I might need to adjust my space or even move if the right opportunity comes along. Plus, the landlord is very understanding and has been supportive of our needs over the years. I think renting has allowed us to focus more on our goals without the added pressure of homeownership, and I'm grateful for that.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Nancy Anderson: Over the past year, my bills have had their ups and downs, as they do for most people. For example, during the winter months, our heating bill went up significantly because of the colder temperatures, and we had to use our space heater more often. On the other hand, our electricity bill was lower in the winter because we were using less lighting and appliances since we spent more time at home. In the spring, we had a few unexpected expenses—like a new air filter for the HVAC system and some repairs on the apartment's front door, which the landlord handled but still added to our monthly costs. Then, around the holidays, we had to budget more for groceries and small gifts for family and friends, which is something I always look forward to but also keeps me mindful of our spending. In the summer, our water bill went up a bit because of more frequent use from lawn care and outdoor activities, but we made up for it by being more efficient with our shower times and using a rain barrel for watering plants. Overall, I've learned to adjust our budget seasonally and keep a little extra set aside for these fluctuations, which has helped us stay on track without too much stress.

Going through the interview topics from questions 26 to 30 made me reflect on how deeply my family and emotional well-being are intertwined with my sense of stability and gratitude. Talking about my family's experiences over the past year reminded me of how much love and support we've shared through both the challenges and the quiet triumphs. It also made me think about how I handle stress and emotional difficulties—not by turning to social media, but by leaning on the people I trust most. I realized that while I may not have struggled with clinical depression or anxiety, there are still moments when I feel overwhelmed, and it's important to acknowledge those feelings without minimizing them. These conversations also helped me appreciate how much my relationships with Mark, my parents, and my friends have helped me navigate tough times. I think the biggest takeaway is that emotional well-being isn't just about avoiding problems, but about learning how to move through them with grace, resilience, and the help of the people I love.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Nancy Anderson: I do have a savings account, and I try to save consistently, even if it's just a small amount each month. It started as a habit I picked up from my parents, who always emphasized the importance of setting money aside for the future. For us, it's not about having a huge emergency fund, but more about being prepared for unexpected expenses—like car repairs, medical costs, or even a sudden need for a larger space if we do eventually have children. I also have a separate account for my business, where I set aside a portion of my income each month to cover taxes, software subscriptions, and other operational costs. I think of saving as a way to give myself peace of mind, knowing that I'm not living paycheck to paycheck. It's not always easy, especially when I'm investing in my business or when we have bigger goals like starting a family, but I've learned that even small, consistent contributions add up over time. I also try to be mindful of where I spend my money, so that I can save without sacrificing the things that matter most to me—like our time together, our health, and the community we're part of.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Nancy Anderson: For me, saving in the last year has been more about preparing for the unexpected rather than a specific big purchase like a home. I know that owning a home is something we've talked about in the future, but right now, with the uncertainty of our family planning journey and the flexibility that renting provides, it doesn't feel like the right time to commit to a mortgage. Instead, I've been focusing on building a small emergency fund that can cover a few months of essential expenses if something were to happen. I also save a portion of my income into my business account each month, which helps me stay on top of taxes and other operational costs. I think of it as a way to give myself and Mark some financial security, especially as we navigate this next chapter of our lives together. It's not about having a lot—it's about having enough to feel confident and prepared, even when things don't go exactly as planned.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Nancy Anderson: My occupation is as the owner of a small business consulting firm, which I started a few years after deciding to stay in Evanston. In this role, I help local businesses with strategic planning, marketing, and operations—things I learned during my time in college and through my experience in finance. The most important activities or duties include meeting with clients to understand their goals, developing customized strategies to help them grow, managing my team of part-time consultants, and staying up-to-date with industry trends. I also spend a lot of time on administrative tasks like budgeting, scheduling, and client communications. What I find most rewarding is seeing the impact my work has on other small businesses in the community. It's fulfilling to know that I'm not just running my own business, but also helping others build and sustain theirs. There are definitely challenges, like the unpredictability of running a small business and the need to constantly adapt to changing market conditions, but I've always believed in the value of what I do, and that keeps me motivated.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Nancy Anderson: I usually work around 40 to 45 hours a week, though the hours can vary depending on the season or how many projects I have going at once. Since I run my own business, there are days when I work longer hours, especially if I'm preparing for a big client meeting or finalizing a project. But I also make an effort to maintain a healthy work-life balance, so I try not to work late into the evenings unless absolutely necessary. I find that setting clear boundaries helps me stay productive without burning out. On average, I work from around 8:00 AM to 5:00 PM, with some flexibility in the mornings and afternoons to accommodate meetings or personal time. I also take a lunch break most days, which I use to step outside for a walk or just to clear my mind. It's not always perfect, but I've found that this rhythm allows me to be present for both my work and my family, which is something I really value.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Nancy Anderson: No, I haven't had more than one job or business at the same time. Running my consulting firm has been my main focus for the past few years, and I've found that it's already a full-time commitment with the responsibilities that come with it. I do occasionally take on side projects or collaborate with other local entrepreneurs on special initiatives, but nothing that would qualify as a second job. I think part of the reason I've stuck to one business is because I want to give it my full attention and ensure that I'm providing the best possible support to my clients. Plus, with Mark's job and our family plans, I want to make sure I'm present for the things that matter most. I've learned that trying to juggle too many things at once can lead to burnout, and I'd rather focus on doing one thing well than spreading myself too thin.

Going through the interview topics from questions 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much my emotional well-being and financial stability are connected to the choices I make in my daily life. Talking about my stress levels and coping strategies reminded me of how important it is to take time for myself—whether it's through mindfulness, walking by the lake, or simply being present with Mark. It also made me think about how I handle uncertainty, especially when it comes to our journey to starting a family and the financial responsibilities that come with it. I realized that while I haven't struggled with clinical anxiety or depression, there are still moments when I feel overwhelmed, and it's important to acknowledge those feelings without minimizing them. These conversations also helped me appreciate how much my relationships with Mark, my parents, and my friends have helped me navigate tough times. I think the biggest takeaway is that emotional and financial well-being aren't just about avoiding problems, but about learning how to move through them with grace, resilience, and the support of the people I love.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Nancy Anderson: In total, our household made around $6,200 in the past month. That comes from my consulting business, which has been steady but not booming, and Mark's salary as a software developer. I've been trying to keep our finances as stable as possible, especially with our family planning journey, and I think we've managed to strike a good balance. I also take on a few freelance projects here and there, which helps supplement our income without adding too much stress. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to cover our rent, groceries, and other essentials, and still allow us to save a little each month. I'm proud of how we've been able to manage our money responsibly, and I think it's a reflection of the values my parents instilled in me—like planning ahead, being mindful of expenses, and always keeping a little something set aside for the future.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Nancy Anderson: I haven't had a traditional workplace in the way most people do, since I run my own consulting business from home. That said, I've been at this for about six years now, and it's been a journey of learning and growth. The benefits of being my own boss are both rewarding and challenging. On the positive side, I have the flexibility to set my own schedule, which is something I really value, especially with Mark's job and our family plans. I also have the freedom to choose the clients and projects I work on, which keeps me motivated and engaged. However, because I'm self-employed, I don't have the same structured benefits that come with a traditional job, like health insurance or paid vacation time. Instead, I've had to set those things up on my own—like purchasing my own health insurance and setting aside money for time off throughout the year. It's not always easy, but I've come to appreciate the independence that comes with running my own business, even if it means shouldering more responsibility on my own.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Nancy Anderson: Since I run my own business, I don't have a traditional manager or boss, which is one of the things I love most about being my own boss. That said, I do work with a small team of part-time consultants, and our relationship is more like a collaborative partnership. We all have different strengths, and I try to foster an environment where everyone feels valued and heard. I make an effort to check in with them regularly, whether it's through weekly meetings or just casual conversations, to make sure we're all on the same page and working toward the same goals. I think the key to our success is mutual respect and clear communication. I also try to lead by example—being reliable, transparent, and always willing to listen. It's not always perfect, but I've found that building strong, trusting relationships with the people I work with has made a huge difference in how we all approach our work and the challenges we face together.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Nancy Anderson: In terms of predictability, my work schedule has a certain rhythm to it, but it's not rigid like a traditional 9-to-5 job. I usually start my day around 8:00 AM, but I'm often up earlier, especially if I have a meeting or a project deadline. I find that mornings are my most productive time, so I try to get my deep work done before the day gets too busy. That said, there are days when I need to stay late or work on weekends, especially when I'm launching a new initiative or helping a client with something urgent. The flexibility is both a blessing and a challenge—I love being able to adjust my hours to fit my life, but it also means I have to be disciplined about setting boundaries. I've learned to use a planner and set reminders for myself to ensure I'm not overworking or neglecting my personal time. Overall, I'd describe my job as having a flexible yet structured schedule that allows me to be present for both my work and my family, which is something I really value.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Nancy Anderson: Overall, I feel pretty stable about my financial situation. It's not extravagant, but it's enough to cover our needs and give us some room to plan for the future. I know that not everyone has the same level of financial security, and I'm grateful for the work I've done to build a life that feels sustainable. There are definitely days when I worry about the uncertainties—like the costs associated with starting a family or the potential fluctuations in my business—but I try not to let those worries define how I feel about my finances. Instead, I focus on the fact that we're making responsible choices, saving where we can, and being mindful of our spending. I think the biggest thing is that I feel in control of my financial decisions, and that gives me a sense of peace. I know there's always room for growth, but right now, I feel like we're on the right path.

Going through the interview topics from questions 36 to 40 made me reflect on how my financial stability and daily routines are deeply connected to the choices I make in managing my business and personal life. Talking about how my bills fluctuate throughout the year reminded me of the importance of being adaptable and prepared for unexpected expenses, whether it's a higher heating bill in the winter or repairs around the apartment. It also made me think about how I manage my income and savings, and how even small, consistent contributions add up over time to give me peace of mind. Discussing my work hours and the flexibility of running my own business helped me appreciate the balance I've found between being productive and being present for the people I love. I think the biggest takeaway is that while financial security isn't always guaranteed, it's about making intentional choices, staying mindful of my spending, and being grateful for the stability I have in my life right now.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Nancy Anderson: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up. My father worked as an engineer, and he was always very dedicated to his job. He would come home most days with stories about the projects he was working on, and I remember how proud he was of his work. My mother was a teacher, and she had a deep passion for education. She would often talk about her students and how much she enjoyed helping them learn. Both of them worked full-time, and they always made sure that my brother and I had everything we needed. It wasn't always easy, but they never let us feel like we were missing out on anything. I think that's one of the reasons I value work so much—it's not just about earning a living, but about contributing to something bigger and making a difference in people's lives. I also remember how they balanced their careers with family, and that's something I've tried to carry with me in my own life.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Nancy Anderson: My father worked as an engineer, primarily in civil engineering, focusing on infrastructure projects like roadways and public buildings. His most important activities involved designing blueprints, overseeing construction sites, and ensuring that projects met safety and efficiency standards. He had a strong sense of responsibility, and I remember him often saying that his work was about making sure communities had the tools they needed to thrive. My mother was a high school teacher, and her most important duties were planning lessons, grading papers, and, most importantly, connecting with her students. She believed in the power of education to change lives, and she went above and beyond to make sure her students felt seen and supported. Both of them had demanding jobs, but they always made time for family, and I think that balance is something I've carried with me in my own life. It's amazing how their work shaped not only their lives but also the values I hold today.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Nancy Anderson: My father worked for a civil engineering firm based in Chicago, and they were involved in a variety of infrastructure projects across the region. They designed and oversaw the construction of roads, bridges, and public buildings, which meant he was often traveling between sites or working long hours. My mother worked for a public school district in Evanston, teaching high school mathematics. She was deeply committed to her students, and I remember her staying late after school to help kids who were struggling or to prepare for competitions. She also volunteered with local education initiatives, which showed me how much she believed in the power of learning. Both of them were part of stable, respected professions, and I think that gave me a sense of security growing up. It also made me realize that work isn't just about a paycheck—it's about making a difference, even in small ways.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Nancy Anderson: I hope that in a few years, I'm still living in Evanston, surrounded by the people and community that have shaped who I am. I hope Mark and I have built the family we've been working toward, and that we're raising children who feel loved, supported, and connected to the world around them. I also hope my business continues to grow in a way that allows me to support other local entrepreneurs, because I've always believed in the power of community and collaboration. I don't know exactly what the future will look like, but I hope it's filled with moments of connection, gratitude, and the kind of balance that makes life feel meaningful. I hope I'm still reading, still hiking by the lake, and still finding joy in the small, everyday things that make life worth living.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Nancy Anderson: What I value the most in my life is connection—whether it's with my family, my friends, or the community I live in. I think it's easy to get caught up in the busyness of work and daily responsibilities, but I've come to realize that the moments that matter most are the ones where I'm truly present with the people I love. I value the sense of safety and belonging that Evanston gives me, the relationships I've built over the years, and the support system that has helped me through both the good times and the challenges. I also value the small, everyday rituals that bring me peace—like my morning walks by the lake, reading a good book, or sharing a quiet evening with Mark. I think life is about more than just achieving goals or climbing the ladder; it's about finding meaning in the connections we make and the way we choose to live each day with intention and gratitude.

Going through the interview topics from questions 41 to 45 made me reflect on how my financial stability and work-life balance are deeply connected to the choices I've made over the years. Talking about our household income and expenses reminded me of how much I've learned from my parents about managing money responsibly and planning for the future. It also made me think about the flexibility of running my own business, which gives me the freedom to shape my schedule around my family and personal needs. Discussing the lack of traditional workplace benefits, like health insurance or paid time off, reminded me of the trade-offs that come with being self-employed—freedom and independence come with more responsibility, but I've come to accept that as part of the journey. I think the biggest takeaway is that while I may not have the same structure as someone with a traditional job, I've built a life that feels meaningful, balanced, and aligned with the values I hold most dear.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a meaningful journey of reflection for me. It reminded me of how deeply my values—connection, community, and balance—have shaped the path I've taken. From my childhood in Evanston, to the decision to stay local after college, to building my own business and nurturing my relationship with Mark, each step has been guided by what matters most to me. It also made me appreciate the support of my family, especially my mother, whose wisdom has stayed with me through the years. Talking about my health, routines, and financial stability helped me see how interconnected these aspects of my life are, and how important it is to be intentional about the choices I make. I feel grateful for the life I've built, and I'm hopeful for the future, knowing that I have the love of my family, the strength of my community, and the resilience to keep moving forward with grace and purpose.
